Eight Of 13 Games Scheduled For Jays To Be Played
At Home, Evergreen
The Johns Hopkins University
basketball quint begins practice for
its 1931-32 season next Monday at
the Loyola College gymnasium,
Arrangem~nts have
Evergreen.
been made with ·~~e authorities of
Loyola to use their; 'basl ,,:'\
. every afternoon oeginning at S P.
M. Practice was to have begun
Monday, November 31, but because
the court was to be used for social
events the entire week the Blue Jay
five was forced to postpone its initial workout of the season.
Delay May Hurt
This defay will undoubtedly hurt
Hopkins considerably in preparing
for its first game with Temple University, as it gives Coach George
Darley only one week to get the
Homewood quint working together.
Last season the Jays lost to Temple
which has its 1930-31 varsity back
almost intact this season.
However, prospects for a highly
successful season are bright as five
letter men will be available. from
last season: D. Kelly, C. Kelly,
Gunnett, Silverman and Brook return, along with Artie Siegal, star
of the 1929-30 quint who was ineligible last season. Several promising freshmen, who played basketball in high school, among whom is
McClean, of Poly, are expected to
be among those to report to the
initial practice next Monday.
13 Games On Schedule
The schedule, as announced by
Walter Frey, manager, consists of
only 13 games.
The Jay quint leaves the State on
only two occasions. It meets Temple on December 15 at Philadelphia,
and Army and Long Island' University in New York on January 8
and 9. This week end, which is to
be spent in New York is always the
outstanding trip in the Blue Jay
schedule.

registrar here reveal. This is an
increase of only one in foreign
representation over that of 1930.

medicine;

political

students. Germany, England, and
Canada each are represented by

Initial Concert To Be Given
At Pro-Cathedral; 12
Numbers On Program
Opening its 1931-32 season the
Musical Club of the Johns Hopkins
University, headed by Ronald Levy,
is to present a concert at the ProCathedral, University Parkway and
St. Paul street, next Monday at 8
P. M.
The program is to be :
( 1) Glee Club: Johns Hopkins
Ode, Trees; (2) Banjo Club: I. H.
U. (march); (3) vocal solo by
Donald Proctor: Danny Deever;
(4 ) banjo duet, by Reich and Gore;
( 5) Hawaiian Troupe: Only You,
Kahola March; (6) Glee Club:
Shenandoah; (7) Banjo Oub: Kiss
Me Again; (8) Blue JaY' Orchestra: Bong of Bayou; (9) Glee
Club: Winter Song, Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins.
The program is to be repeated
next Friday night at the Forest
Park Presbyterian Church. The fol1owing evening, December 12, the
Glee Oub alone is to appear on the
Fraternal Relief Week program at
the Fifth Regiment Armory.
In addition to Levy the other of·ficers of the Musical Club are Milton Smith and Wilson Shugernan.
both of whom are business managers of the organization_

Dr. Allan K. Chalmers, ]. H. U.
Grad To Talk At Supper Club,
Graduate Luncheon

Dr. Alan Knight Chalmers,
minister of the Broadway Tabernacle in New York City, who
was graduated from the Johns
Hopkins in 1918, will visit the
Homewood campus next Tuesday and wil speak at the luncheon for graduate students. His
theme will be "Does It Make Any
Difference What A Man Believes
About God?" The price 9f the
luncheon will be thirty-five cents,
Dr. Chalmers will also meet
the cabinet of the Y M. C. A. at
4:00 P. M., and at 6:30 P. M. he
is to address the University Supper Club on "Individuality With
A Difference."
An 0. D. K. man, Dr. Chalmers
studied for the ministry at Yale
and received his degree in 1922.
He became pastor of the First
Presbyterian Church in Buffalo
and succeeded Charles E. J efferson to the position he now holds.
Dr. Chalmers spoke before the
Sunday Evening Club in Chicago
recently and drew an audience· of
nearly 4,000.

An audience which is hoped to
fill the Lyric Theatre to its capacity
is expected to view tonight the •
opening performance of "Setret
Service," a four-act melodrama to
be presented by the Barnstormers
of the Johns Hopkins University.
Tomorrow evening the play, the
eleventh annual production by the
Homewood dramatic group, is to
be offered again. Following both
performances, which are to begin
at 8 :15 P. M., a dance, sponsored
by Miss Emily Bolgiano, the heroine in the play, is to be held at the
Knights of Pythias ball room,
Charles and Preston Streets. Steinwald's Orchestra is to supply the
music.
The cast for "Secret Service" by
William Gillette, which was under
the direction of William Banks and
Howard Caplan, both Hopkins
alumni and former 'Stormers, includes several who have had "leads"
in previous Barnstormer productions.
Cast Chosen
The cast for "Secret Service" is
as follows:

"Secret Service" takes place during the Civil War in the city of
Richmond which is being beseiged
by the Union Army. From the very
rising of the curtain, there is shown
the extreme tenseness and suff~ring
of those living behind the hardpressed lines. The greater part of
the action in the first, second and
fourth acts takes place in the Var'ney home. Edith Varney, the heroine, portrayed by Miss Bolgiano, is
the daughter of the _house. Captain Thorne, played by Farinholt, a
Union spy, has installed himself in
Richmond as a Confederate captain
detained on account of a severe
wound. He and Edith fall in love
with each other. She, in order~ o
save Thorne from having to return
to the Front, procures for hin;i a
commission, assigning him to the
Government telegraph office in
Richmond. ·

SECRET SERVICE

Tonight at 8 :15 P . M. "The
Barnstormers" will give their first
performance of this year's annual
production. "Secret Service," by
William Gillette, will be enacted by
the 'Stormers tonight and tomorrow
night on the Lyric stage.
" Secret Service" is a Civil War
melodrama and the locale of the
play is the Confederate Capitol,
Richmond, Virginia, during the
siege of this important Confederate
stronghold by the Yankee soldiers,
who are entrenched in a strong position, just outside of the city.
The main action of the play centered around the activities of a
northern spy who has joined the
southern army with the expressed
intentions of discovering the plans
of the southerners and then getting
this knowledge back to his cohorts,
the Yankees. However, he encounters some entanglements in the form
of a beautiful southern girl. He
falls madly in love with her, and
she, strangely enough, discovers a
very soft spot in her heart for him.
The working out of these pertinent
problems affords the action for the
play. He is caught between two
flames, as it were. He naturally
does not want to do anything that - - - - - - - - - - - - - - . .
will harm her or her people, and to

Tau Beta Pi, national honorary
engineering fraternity, will hold
its annual Fall initiation at the
assembly next Thursday, it was
said today.
A poly-phase duplex slide rule
will also be awarded to that Engineer in last year's freshman
class who was the most outstanding in scholarship and the
qualities required for membership in Tau Beta Pi. These qualities are good personality, leadership, adaptibility, activities on
the campus, and fellowship.

The Johns Hopkins University
basketball quint begins practice for

Arrangem~nts have
Evergreen.
been made with ·~~e authorities of

five was forced to postpone its initial workout of the season.
Delay May Hurt
This defay will undoubtedly hurt
Hopkins considerably in preparing
for its first game with Temple University, as it gives Coach George
Darley only one week to get the
Homewood quint working together.
Last season the Jays lost to Temple
which has its 1930-31 varsity back
almost intact this season.

successful season are bright as five
letter men will be available. from
last season: D. Kelly, C. Kelly,
Gunnett, Silverman and Brook return, along with Artie Siegal, star

McClean, of Poly, are expected to
be among those to report to the
initial practice next Monday.

Walter Frey, manager, consists of
only 13 games.

only two occasions. It meets Temple on December 15 at Philadelphia,
and Army and Long Island' University in New York on January 8
and 9. This week end, which is to
be spent in New York is always the
outstanding trip in the Blue Jay
schedule.

Grad To Talk At Supper Club,
Graduate Luncheon

Dr. Alan Knight Chalmers,
minister of the Broadway Tabernacle in New York City, who
was graduated from the Johns
Hopkins in 1918, will visit the
Homewood campus next Tuesday and wil speak at the luncheon for graduate students. His
theme will be "Does It Make Any
Difference What A Man Believes
About God?" The price 9f the
luncheon will be thirty-five cents,
Dr. Chalmers will also meet
the cabinet of the Y M. C. A. at
4:00 P. M., and at 6:30 P. M. he
is to address the University Supper Club on "Individuality With
A Difference."
An 0. D. K. man, Dr. Chalmers
studied for the ministry at Yale
and received his degree in 1922.
He became pastor of the First
Presbyterian Church in Buffalo
and succeeded Charles E. J efferson to the position he now holds.
Dr. Chalmers spoke before the
Sunday Evening Club in Chicago
recently and drew an audience· of
nearly 4,000.

An audience which is hoped to
fill the Lyric Theatre to its capacity
is expected to view tonight the •
opening performance of "Setret
Service," a four-act melodrama to
be presented by the Barnstormers
of the Johns Hopkins University.
Tomorrow evening the play, the
eleventh annual production by the
Homewood dramatic group, is to
be offered again. Following both
performances, which are to begin
at 8 :15 P. M., a dance, sponsored
by Miss Emily Bolgiano, the heroine in the play, is to be held at the
Knights of Pythias ball room,
Charles and Preston Streets. Steinwald's Orchestra is to supply the
music.
The cast for "Secret Service" by
William Gillette, which was under
the direction of William Banks and
Howard Caplan, both Hopkins
alumni and former 'Stormers, includes several who have had "leads"
in previous Barnstormer productions.

"Secret Service" takes place during the Civil War in the city of
Richmond which is being beseiged
by the Union Army. From the very
rising of the curtain, there is shown
the extreme tenseness and suff~ring
of those living behind the hardpressed lines. The greater part of
the action in the first, second and
fourth acts takes place in the Var'ney home. Edith Varney, the heroine, portrayed by Miss Bolgiano, is
the daughter of the _house. Captain Thorne, played by Farinholt, a
Union spy, has installed himself in
Richmond as a Confederate captain
detained on account of a severe
wound. He and Edith fall in love
with each other. She, in order~ o
save Thorne from having to return
to the Front, procures for hin;i a
commission, assigning him to the
Government telegraph office in
Richmond. ·

Tonight at 8 :15 P . M. "The
Barnstormers" will give their first
performance of this year's annual
production. "Secret Service," by
William Gillette, will be enacted by
the 'Stormers tonight and tomorrow
night on the Lyric stage.
" Secret Service" is a Civil War
melodrama and the locale of the
play is the Confederate Capitol,
Richmond, Virginia, during the
siege of this important Confederate
stronghold by the Yankee soldiers,
who are entrenched in a strong position, just outside of the city.
The main action of the play centered around the activities of a
northern spy who has joined the
southern army with the expressed
intentions of discovering the plans
of the southerners and then getting
this knowledge back to his cohorts,
the Yankees. However, he encounters some entanglements in the form
of a beautiful southern girl. He
falls madly in love with her, and
she, strangely enough, discovers a
very soft spot in her heart for him.
The working out of these pertinent
problems affords the action for the
play. He is caught between two
flames, as it were. He naturally
does not want to do anything that - - - - - - - - - - - - - - . .
